{{ NCAATeamSeason | Mode = football | Year = 1910 | Team = Nebraska Cornhuskers | Logo = | LogoSize = | LogoAlt = | Image = 1910 Nebraska Cornhuskers football team.jpg | ImageSize = | ImageAlt = | Conference = Missouri Valley Intercollegiate Athletic Association | Division = | ShortConference = MVIAA | BCSRank = | CoachRank = | APRank = | Record = 7-1-0 | ConfRecord = 2-0-0 | WinsVacated = | WinsForfeited = | ConfWinsVacated = | ConfWinsForfeited = | HeadCoach = [[William C. "King" Cole]] | HCYear = 4th | OffCoach = | OCYear = | DefCoach = | DCYear = | OScheme = | DScheme = | StadiumArena = [[Nebraska Field]] | Champion = Missouri Valley Champions | BowlTourney = | BowlTourneyResult = | ConfChamp = | ConfChampResult = }} {{1910 Missouri Valley football standings}} The '''1910 Nebraska Cornhuskers football team''' was the representative of the [[University of Nebraska-Lincoln|University of Nebraska]] in the [[1910 college football season]]. The team was coached by [[William C. "King" Cole]] and played their home games at [[Nebraska Field]] in [[Lincoln, Nebraska]]. ==Before the season== Coach Cole may have come into his 4th year with a bit of a chip on his shoulder. His first and second season teams had each contributed to improving Nebraska's overall program winning percentage, but the previous year's 3-3-2 final tally had been a setback. ==Schedule== {{Cite web|url=http://www.huskers.com/SportSelect.dbml?SPSID=3&SPID=22&DB_OEM_ID=100&KEY=&Q_SEASON=1910 |title =Football - 1910 Schedule/Results |accessdate=2009-11-16|publisher=University of Nebraska-Lincoln Athletics Department}} {| class="wikitable" |- ! Ewing|Harry Ewing]]'''|||Assistant Coach||align="center"| ||align="center"| ||[[University of NebraskaâLincoln|Nebraska]] |}{{Cite web|url=http://www.huskermax.com/coaches.html|title=Nebraska head coaches|accessdate=2009-11-16|publisher=HuskerMax}}{{Cite web|url=http://yearbooks.unl.edu/yearbook.php?year=1911&page=175|title=1911 Cornhusker - University of Nebraska Yearbook|accessdate=2009-11-16|publisher=University of NebraskaâLincoln Libraries}} ==Game notes== ===Peru State===
'''Peru State at Nebraska'''
1234Total
[[Peru State College|Peru State]] 0
'''â¢ Nebraska''' 66
* '''Date:''' 1910-10-01 * '''Location:''' Nebraska Field â¢ [[Lincoln, Nebraska]]
Nebraska used this final meeting with Peru State as a tuneup practice game, playing backups and determining the starting lineup for the season. The Cornhuskers closed out their series with Peru State with a perfect record of 3-0. {{Cite web|url=http://www.huskermax.com/1910s.html|title=the 1910s|accessdate=2009-11-16|publisher=HuskerMax}} {{-}} ===South Dakota===
'''South Dakota at Nebraska'''
1234Total
[[South Dakota Coyotes football|South Dakota]] 9
'''â¢ Nebraska''' 12
* '''Date:''' 1910-10-08 * '''Location:''' Nebraska Field â¢ Lincoln, Nebraska
The Cornhuskers won yet another in an increasingly one-sided series with the Coyotes, improving to 5-1-1 against South Dakota. {{-}} ===Minnesota===
'''Nebraska at Minnesota'''
1234Total
Nebraska 3
'''â¢ [[1910 Minnesota Golden Gophers football team|Minnesota]]''' 21
* '''Date:''' 1910-10-15 * '''Location:''' Northrop Field â¢ [[Minneapolis|Minneapolis, Minnesota]]
Nebraska's stretch of frustration continued, as once again the Golden Gophers soundly defeated the Cornhuskers in Minneapolis, leaving Nebraska winless in the series since 1902. Minnesota's series lead increased to 8-1-1. {{-}} ===Denver===
'''Denver at Nebraska'''
1234Total
[[Denver Pioneers|Denver]] 0
'''â¢ Nebraska''' 27
* '''Date:''' 1910-10-22 * '''Location:''' Nebraska Field â¢ Lincoln, Nebraska
For the first time in the series, Denver traveled to Lincoln to face the Cornhuskers at home, but this game would also be the last meeting between the squads. Coming off the Minnesota loss, the team came together to function as a unit and also successfully implemented some new plays. The Cornhuskers finished out the series with another win and stayed perfect over Denver at 4-0. {{-}} ===Doane===
'''Doane at Nebraska'''
1234Total
[[Doane College|Doane]] 0
'''â¢ Nebraska''' 6
* '''Date:''' 1910-10-29 * '''Location:''' Nebraska Field â¢ Lincoln, Nebraska
Nebraska did not have as easy a time putting away Doane as in other recent meetings of the past few years, but still kept their win streak against Doane alive with the 6-0 win, owning the series 14-2. {{-}} ===Kansas===
'''Nebraska at Kansas'''
1234Total
'''â¢ Nebraska''' 6
{{cfb link|year=1910|school=University of Kansas|team=Kansas Jayhawks|title=Kansas}} 0
* '''Date:''' 1910-11-05 * '''Location:''' Central Park â¢ [[Lawrence, Kansas]]
For the second week in a row, Nebraska survived a hard fought and low scoring affair, escaping with a repeat 6-0 win. Nebraska secured at least a share of the conference title with the win, and took the lead in the series again, 9-8. {{-}} ===Iowa State===
'''Iowa State at Nebraska'''
1234Total
{{cfb link|year=1910|school=Iowa State University|team=Iowa State Cyclones|title=Iowa State}} 0
'''â¢ Nebraska''' 24
* '''Date:''' 1910-11-12 * '''Location:''' Nebraska Field â¢ Lincoln, Nebraska
The Cornhuskers put up 24 unanswered points to secure their 4th straight shutout victory to close their abbreviated conference slate. The win secured Nebraska's position as sole conference champions, and moved Nebraska farther ahead in their series with Iowa State to 8-3. {{-}} ===Haskell===
'''Haskell at Nebraska'''
1234Total
[[Haskell Indian Nations University|Haskell]] 0
'''â¢ Nebraska''' 119
* '''Date:''' 1910-11-24 * '''Location:''' Nebraska Field â¢ Lincoln, Nebraska
Nebraska absolutely annihilated Haskell in coach Cole's final game, completely exploding for a record setting 119-0 victory, a team scoring and margin of victory record that has stood for one hundred years. The Cornhuskers piled up an astonishing 1,150 yards of offense, while Haskell managed only 67 yards in their 17 total plays in the game. Nebraska improved over Haskell all-time to 5-2. {{Cite web|url=http://www.huskernews.com/vnews/display.v/ART/2001/02/20/3a9331482|title=From The Past: 119-0|accessdate=2009-11-16|publisher=Husker Press Box}} {{-}} ==After the season== Coach Cole went out in style with the record-setting 119-0 blasting delivered to Haskell at Nebraska Field. His four-year record stood at 25-8-3 (.736), and his teams improved the program's overall record to 118-45-8 (.713). Coach Cole's conference record ended at 5-2-1 (.688), winning a share of the 1907 conference title and winning the 1910 title in his final year outright. ==References== {{Reflist}} {{NebraskaCornhuskersFootballNavbox}} {{DEFAULTSORT:1910 Nebraska Cornhuskers Football Team}} [[Category:1910 NCAA football season|Nebraska]] [[Category:Nebraska Cornhuskers football seasons]]
